conclusion: Let the horizontal distance from the point-light source to the wall be 2L.
The ball is launched from the midpoint, L from either end.
At any time t its height above the floor is h(t) = v₀ t – ½ g t².
Draw the ray joining the source (x = 0) to the ball (x = L); it meets the wall at x = 2L, casting the shadow.
From similar triangles, h(t) / L = H(t) / (2L) ⇒ H(t) = 2 h(t), where H(t) is the shadow’s height on the wall.
Velocity is the time-derivative of height.
At the launch instant t = 0, v_shadow(0) = 2 v₀.
Therefore the shadow starts upward with twice the ball’s initial speed.
Answer: the initial velocity of the shadow is 2 v₀ (upward).
